transcript.text: so what we call good english
is a system which is partly artificial i
should say which is taught to people
because it was legislated to be good
english not some of what it's taught
it breaks the rules of any conceivable
human language that's why it has to be
taught over and over again so i don't
know if people still do it in school but
when i was in school you had to learn
all sorts of complicated nonsense about
shall and will which nobody could ever
remember i mean i forget what it worked
i i shall you will or some strange thing
i mean there are certain principles of
human biology which determine what a
language can be and no language can be
like that so that had to be in fact we
you can trace that back and you can find
out who invented it you know some bishop
in the 17th century or something
invented and decided that's the way it's
supposed to be now that kind of thing of
course has to be taught because it's
totally artificial these terms have no
linguistic meaning they have only
socio-political meaning of a very
complex sort the way in which they
interact with authority structures is
crucial
